terms.definition: A professional responsible for designing, integrating, and optimizing complex systems that combine hardware and software components to meet specific requirements and standards.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and understand the evolution of content.
The process of creating, organizing, storing, and maintaining documents throughout their lifecycle to ensure accuracy, accessibility, and compliance.
A single, unified location where all documents, files, and resources are stored and managed, providing easy access and organization for teams.
The systematic monitoring and documentation of adherence to regulatory standards, industry requirements, and internal policies.
Documents that are organized, complete, and easily accessible in a format that meets regulatory audit requirements and can be quickly retrieved for review.
The ability to track and document the history of changes, decisions, and relationships between different components or documents throughout a project lifecycle.
The complete process of a system from initial design and development through implementation, maintenance, and eventual retirement.
Federal Aviation Administration - the U.S. government agency responsible for regulating and overseeing aviation safety and standards.
European Union Aviation Safety Agency - the European regulatory body responsible for civil aviation safety standards and certification.
International Traffic in Arms Regulations - U.S. regulations that control the export and import of defense-related articles and services.
The control system that determines which users can access, view, edit, or share specific documents or resources within a platform.
The ability for multiple users to work on the same document or project simultaneously, with changes visible to all participants instantly.
The process of combining different subsystems and components into a unified, functional system that works together seamlessly.
Electronic systems used in aircraft, including communication, navigation, flight control, and monitoring equipment.
